channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rise in Cases and Deaths Tests Britain’s Gamble on Few Virus Restrictions
item.description: The country’s grand experiment — opening up with hardly any restrictions — is facing its toughest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers and commuters on Thursday in Newcastle upon Tyne, in northeast England. Britain’s daily Covid infection rate is now triple that of Germany, France and Spain combined.

item.title: In Haiti, Gangs Gain Power as Security Vacuum Grows
item.description: Gangs have long held sway in the country, but their dominance has expanded in recent years and the government has been accused of using them as tools of repression.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the G9 gang protesting peacefully in July in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, over the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse.

item.title: Why Australia Won’t Commit to Slashing Carbon Emissions
item.description: The country has fallen behind other developed nations in its commitment to slashing carbon emissions. Neither fires nor international pressure has pushed it away from coal and other fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Collinsville coal mine in Queensland, Australia. The country is the world’s largest coal exporter.

item.title: As Chinese Women Seek to Crack Male Professions, Schools Stand in the Way
item.description: In China, some academic programs accept only men or cap the number of female applicants, who often must test higher than their male counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:description: A graduation ceremony at Renmin University in Beijing last year.

item.title: U.K. Police Charge Suspect in David Amess Killing
item.description: Ali Harbi Ali, 25, was accused of murder and preparation of terrorist acts in the killing of David Amess, who was fatally stabbed last week.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Paying tribute to David Amess outside Parliament on Monday.

item.title: Syria Executes 24 People for Setting Wildfires, Calling It ‘Terrorism’
item.description: The sentences shocked rights groups, who saw it as a move by President Bashar al-Assad to appear tough after a crisis that hurt his loyalists.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers and local residents battling a fire west of Hama Province in September 2020.

item.title: New Zealand’s Chief Coroner Opens New Inquiry Into Mosque Attacks
item.description: The move came after pleas from dozens of families of those killed in 2019 when a white supremacist opened fire on Muslims at prayer.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Graham-McLay
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial to victims of the mass shooting in Christchurch, New Zealand, in March 2019.

item.title: Celtics Games Are Pulled in China After Enes Kanter’s Pro-Tibet Posts
item.description: The Boston center called China’s leader, Xi Jinping, a “brutal dictator” on social media, igniting an online backlash in the country. The N.B.A.’s online partner stopped streaming the team’s games.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Sopan Deb
item.media:description: After Enes Kanter, right, posted a tweet criticizing China’s president, the company Tencent indicated that upcoming Celtics games would not be livestreamed.

item.title: Female Afghan Judges and Lawyers Now Fear For Their Lives
item.description: They fear that they or their loved ones could be tracked down and killed because of their work delivering justice to women. “We have lost everything — our jobs, our homes, the way we lived.”
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: “A dark future is awaiting everyone in Afghanistan, especially female judges,” said Nabila, a former judge. Their plight is another example of the Taliban’s unraveling of gains made by women.

item.title: ‘No Girls’: Women in Egypt Fight to Get Judgeships
item.description: On paper, women are free to apply for seats on Egyptian benches. In practice, they say, it is near impossible.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar
item.media:description: A swearing-in ceremony this week for 98 women appointed to a top Egyptian court. They were appointed at the behest of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and already employed by the state.

item.title: Transgender Woman Flees Malaysia After Wearing Hijab
item.description: The Islamic authorities want to imprison her for wearing female clothing at a religious event and threatened to put her in a rehabilitation camp where she could “return to the right path.”
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Hadi Azmi
item.media:credit: Faye Sakura for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of Nur Sajat at a hotel in Australia this month, taken during a video chat with the photographer.

item.title: Queen ‘Reluctantly’ Cancels Trip, Citing Medical Advice
item.description: Britain’s 95-year-old monarch will not travel to Northern Ireland but is “in good spirits,” Buckingham Palace said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II attended a reception for international business and investment leaders at Windsor Castle on Tuesday.

item.title: Blinken Cites ‘Democratic Reckoning’ in South America
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned of an eroding trust in democracy in the Western Hemisphere and described challenges posed to open government by authoritarian leaders.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: “What can we do to make democracies deliver on the issues that matter most to our people?” Secretary of State Anthony J. Blinken asked during an address in Quito, Ecuador, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Moves to Allow Entry to Vaccinated Tourists
item.description: The plan to reopen to international tourists for the first time since the pandemic began comes as infections are steadily declining in Israel after a fourth wave.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: People arriving at the Ben Gurion International Airport in Lod, near Tel Aviv, last May, when immediate relatives who were vaccinated were allowed to enter the country.

item.title: N.I.H. Says Bat Research Group Failed to Submit Prompt Virus Findings
item.description: The federal agency told a G.O.P. House member that it had notified EcoHealth Alliance, a group criticized for its U.S.-funded work with Wuhan scientists, to file data within five days.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Dr. Francis Collins, the director of the N.I.H., in May. N.I.H. officials have rejected claims that coronaviruses studied with federal funding might have produced the pandemic.

item.title: With Covid Cases Rising, Moscow's Mayor Announces Lockdown
item.description: Like many countries, Russia has seesawed between tighter and looser pandemic restrictions. As the coronavirus claims more victims, the pendulum is now swinging toward tightening.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A patient arriving at a Covid-focused hospital in Moscow last week. On Thursday, the city announced a return to some of the tightest restrictions in a year, including closing shops and restaurants.

item.title: Canada Settles on a Single 'Vaccine Passport' for Travel
item.description: The document, already in use in five of the country’s 10 provinces and all three of its territories, will replace a patchwork of programs across Canada.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau visiting a vaccination clinic in Ottawa in September. Canada is rolling out a national vaccine passport to standardize proof of immunization.

item.title: With Splendor and Saints, Hispanic Society Shows Its Treasures
item.description: This gem of a museum in Upper Manhattan has reopened with an operatic eye-filler of religious sculptures we’re just learning to appreciate.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter

item.title: Bulgaria Faces a Surge in Coronavirus Cases
item.dc:creator: Boryana Dzhambazova
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:description: Protesters gathering in front of the Council of Ministers during a rally against the mandatory Covid-19 health pass, in Sofia, Bulgaria, on Wednesday.

item.title: Tourists in Asia Navigate a Patchwork of Policies
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jin Yu Young
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Tourists on a beach in Bali on Tuesday, after Indonesia began allowing tourists from 19 countries.

item.title: South Korea’s First Homemade Rocket Lifts Off but Is ‘One Step Short’
item.description: The country aspires to be a leader in space technology, with plans to land an uncrewed craft on the moon by 2030. President Moon Jae-in said the initial launch was excellent “for a first try.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Nuri, South Korea’s first domestically produced space rocket, sitting on its launch pad at the Naro Space Center in Goheung on Thursday.

item.title: The Full Truth
item.description: What happens when health officials tell it?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director, at a hearing in July.

item.title: India's Covid Vaccine Campaign Hits 1 Billion Doses
item.description: More than 70 percent of India’s adult population has now received at least one dose of a vaccine. Bulgaria, with the E.U.’s lowest vaccination rate, faces a case surge.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar, Natasha Frost and Boryana Dzhambazova
item.media:description: A health worker inoculating a woman with the Covaxin vaccine at a health center in New Delhi, India, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Plans to extract more fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Work on a new petroleum plant in eastern Russia last year.

item.title: The Webb Telescope’s Latest Stumbling Block: Its Name
item.description: The long-awaited successor to the Hubble Space Telescope is scheduled to launch in December. But the NASA official for whom it is named has been accused of homophobia.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: Integrating two major pieces of the James Webb space telescope in a Northrop Grumman cleanroom in Redondo Beach, Calif., this year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s ‘non-working’ week.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Butovskoye cemetery, which serves as one of Moscow’s Covid death burial grounds.

item.title: Brazil Senate’s Pandemic Panel, in Last-Minute Shift, Softened Criminal Recommendations on Bolsonaro
item.description: Senators on the 11-member panel had second thoughts about the provability of homicide and genocide charges. Instead, they accused the president of “crimes against humanity.”
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against Jair Bolsonaro, the Brazilian president, in São Paulo earlier this month.

item.title: Iran Plans to Abandon One of Its Homegrown Covid Shots
item.description: The defense ministry said there was too little demand for its Fakhravac vaccine to justify producing it, and blamed the health ministry for reneging on promised orders.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: An Iranian student receiving a Covid-19 vaccine in Tehran.

item.title: Egypt imposes a vaccine mandate for all government workers and university students.
item.description: Officials expect major deliveries of doses by the end of the month to speed up the country’s vaccination efforts.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan
item.media:description: Covid vaccinations underway in Cairo in September.

item.title: Spanish Court Agrees to Extradite Former Venezuela Spy Chief to U.S.
item.description: Hugo Carvajal, once a prominent figure in the government of the Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro, faces drug-trafficking charges in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The former Venezuelan intelligence chief Hugo Carvajal during a hearing last month at the National Court in Madrid.

item.title: Britain Resists Calls to Introduce Covid Restrictions
item.description: The number of new cases in Britain is among the highest in the world, but the government has said there is no need to impose indoor mask mandates or other restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: People lining up for a sold-out opening day screening of the new James Bond film "No Time To Die" last month in London.

item.title: Turkey Sours on Syrians, but Not in This Sleepy Town, Jolted Awake
item.description: As calls increase in Turkey for Syrian refugees to go home, Kilis, a border town transformed by the newcomers’ energy, has embraced the change.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main bazaar in Kilis, southern Turkey.

item.title: Ancient-DNA Researchers Set Ethics Guidelines for Their Work
item.description: New, international standards for handling ancient genetic material draw support from many scientists, criticism from others.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A technician in the lab of David Reich, a paleogeneticist at Harvard, sandblasting a bone several thousand years old to isolate and extract DNA.

item.title: Russia Introduces Weeklong Office Shutdown After Covid Deaths Rise
item.description: The measure, meant to slow the spread of the coronavirus, is short of a full lockdown and only affects nonessential workers.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A policeman and a Russian National Guard serviceman on patrol near the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia on May 2, 2021, during a non-working period imposed by President Vladimir Putin to control the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Gates Foundation Pledges $120 Million to Help Get Merck Covid Pills to Poor Countries
item.description: Regulatory hurdles and supply chain issues could slow efforts to produce generic versions of Merck’s antiviral molnupiravir for developing nations, despite licensing agreements.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Molnupiravir is a simple pill. A large clinical trial found that it halved the risk of hospitalizations and death from Covid among high-risk people who took it soon after infection.

item.title: Navalny, Putin’s Imprisoned Foe, Wins E.U.’s Top Human Rights Award
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who survived an assassination attempt only to be jailed, received the Sakharov Prize.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Aina J. Khan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny at a march in Moscow in February 2020. He has remained an unflinching critic of President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Putin Won’t Go to Glasgow for Climate Conference
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may make a speech by video at the United Nations summit, which is seen as pivotal in efforts to stem climate change.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Sergei Guneyev/Agence France-Presse, via Sputnik/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin attending a session of the Russian Energy Week International Forum in Moscow last week.

item.title: Heavy Rains in India and Nepal Kill Dozens
item.description: The death toll continued to rise on Wednesday as landslides and flooding damaged homes and stranded thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Cars submerged at a flooded resort after extreme rainfall caused the Kosi River to overflow in Uttarakhand, India.

item.title: Bombing of Military Bus in Syrian Capital Kills 14
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad has tightened his grip on Damascus, but the attack suggested that militants who oppose him can still do harm.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Syrian firefighters and security officers checking a burned bus at the site of an explosion in Damascus on Wednesday, in a photo released by the Syrian state news agency, SANA.

item.title: Where Are the Workers?
item.description: How can so many Americans afford not to work? And will it last?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A job fair in Santa Clara, Calif.

item.title: Writing About a Past Injustice Helped Her See What Has and Hasn’t Changed
item.description: Nadifa Mohamed is a Booker Prize finalist for her novel “The Fortune Men,” a story about a false accusation and the tragedy that resulted.
item.dc:creator: Geneva Abdul
item.media:credit: Adama Jalloh for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s easy to be loved if you keep quiet,” said Nadifa Mohamed, the author of “The Fortune Men.” “I think I’d rather be heard than silent and loved.”

item.title: 1971: Paris Installs Giant Air Filters to Combat Pollution
item.description: Two towers, each measuring 16 and a half feet high, were installed in an area in the east of the city in an experiment to tackle contamination.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Calls to charge Bolsonaro with crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against Jair Bolsonaro, the Brazilian president, in São Paulo earlier this month.

item.title: In-N-Out Burger Was Briefly Closed for Breaking San Francisco Covid Protocols
item.description: The popular burger chain said it refused to become “the vaccination police for any government.”
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz

item.title: Fox News Anchor Neil Cavuto Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: The broadcaster has survived cancer and open-heart surgery and has multiple sclerosis.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:description: Fox News host Neil Cavuto learned on Monday that he had tested positive for Covid.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Vaccine milestones in Australia and on tiny Pacific islands.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: People dined at a restaurant earlier this month in Sydney, Australia, after coronavirus lockdowns were lifted.

item.title: Britain Outlines Energy Plans Amid Dimming Prospects for Climate Summit
item.description: In an effort to recapture momentum, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a host of measures, including plans for a big expansion of electric vehicles, more offshore wind power and greater use of hydrogen.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain speaking at the Global Investment Summit at the Science Museum in London on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S.-Venezuela Tensions Heat Up Again After Extradition of Maduro Ally
item.description: As Secretary of State Antony Blinken heads to the region, the window of opportunity for a political resolution has slammed shut. At least for now.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro has called off negotiations with his political opponents and detained six U.S. oil executives, derailing any glimmer of rapprochement as Venezuela’s economy crumbles.

item.title: Bolsonaro's Pandemic Response Draws Claim of Crimes Against Humanity
item.description: A report from lawmakers initially said Jair Bolsonaro should be charged with mass homicide and genocide, accusing him of letting Covid-19 spread in a failed bid for herd immunity.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against President Jair Bolsonaro this month in São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: School Attendance Falls for Homeless Students in N.Y.C.
item.description: Attendance rates for students living in shelters fell to just 73 percent in the first few weeks of the new school year, compared with around 90 percent for all students.
item.dc:creator: Precious Fondren
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bayside High School in Queens in September. Homeless students in New York City already faced obstacles to attending school, and the pandemic has added more.

item.title: They Fought Apartheid in South Africa. Now They Want Veterans’ Benefits.
item.description: A protest movement by those who took up arms against apartheid has grown confrontational. More than 50 of them have been charged with kidnapping the country’s defense minister.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A group of 53 veterans of the armed struggle against apartheid in South Africa are accused of kidnapping the country’s defense minister and other government officials. The veterans attended a hearing on Tuesday in Pretoria.

item.title: Ukraine's Covid Deaths Soar as Fake Vaccination Certificates Spread
item.description: In the country with the lowest rate of coronavirus vaccination in Europe, the proliferation of fakes threatens to undermine Ukraine’s fight against the virus.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova

item.title: A Warning That Africa’s Last Glaciers Will Soon Vanish
item.description: While African nations contribute less than 4 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions, a U.N. report underscored the outsize impact that climate change is having on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A glacier on Mount Kilimanjaro, Tanzania, in 2010. The report paints a disturbing picture of both the impacts to date and the consequences to come if urgent action on climate change is not taken.

item.title: Mix-and-Match Covid Boosters: Why They Just Might Work
item.description: The F.D.A. may authorize booster shots of vaccines different from the ones that Americans originally received. The science behind the move is promising.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: Vaccinations typically consist of two or more doses of the same vaccine, but the F.D.A. is expected to authorize a mix-and-match strategy.

item.title: Thousands Flee Myanmar for India Amid Fears of a Growing Refugee Crisis
item.description: For decades, armed conflict, political repression and targeted campaigns against minorities have forced hundreds of thousands of people to leave the country. Now many more are expected to follow.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refugee carrying his grandmother to the shore of Mizoram, India, after crossing the Tiau River from Myanmar.

item.title: Kidnappers in Haiti Demand $17 Million to Free Missionary Group
item.description: A gang abducted 17 people associated with a Christian aid group, including five children. Most of those being held are Americans; one is Canadian.
item.dc:creator: Andre Paultre, Constant Méheut and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Christian Aid Ministries compound in Titenyen, Haiti, houses missionaries working in the country. Seventeen people affiliated with the group were kidnapped on Saturday.

item.title: Transgender U.S. Public Health Official Breaks Ground in Covid Fight
item.description: Admiral Rachel Levine is the first female four-star admiral in the history of the he U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps, which she already leads in her role as assistant secretary.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Nate Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Rachel Levine has been sworn in as a four-star admiral in the U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps, which she already leads in her role as assistant secretary.

item.title: Taliban Allow Polio Vaccine Program to Restart in Afghanistan
item.description: Taliban leaders also agreed to allow women to be frontline workers for the effort, according to the World Health Organization and UNICEF.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: A health worker administering a dose to a baby during a polio vaccination campaign in Kabul, Afghanistan, in June.
